newsitem.title: CANADA: Dryness slows Saskatchewan grain disease.
newsitem.headline: Dryness slows Saskatchewan grain disease.

text.p: The development of cereal crop diseases in Saskatchewan slowed on drier weather, a Saskatchewan Agriculture agrologist said.

"Generally, wheat and barley, with the heat and drier weather we've been experiencing through the province, disease problems are being slowed down," said Ken Panchuk, cereal agrologist at Saskatchewan Agriculture.
Saskatchewan farmers seeded 17.175 million acres to all types of wheat and 4.5 million acres to barley this year, Statistics Canada said on June 27.
"There's wet pockets where disease is spreading," Panchuk said. "But it's small because, overall, the province needs rain soon."
Insect threats to cereal production, however, were difficult to assess.
"We are now actively controlling wheat midge and the area of control at this time is too early to tell but we are actively applying control measures," Panchuk said.
Wheat midge are small orange flies that lay eggs on newly emerged heads of wheat.
About half of Saskatchewan's wheat crop was heading as of the week ended, Saskatchewan Agriculture said.
